Explanations about Options.-o:
Place output in file file. This applies to whatever sort of output is being produced,
 whether it be an executable file, an object file, an assembler file or preprocessed C
 code.
Explanations about Options.-:
"div" and "ddiv" do not always produce the correct result if one of the operands
 is negative.
Explanations about Options.-c:
If any of these options is used, then the linker is not run, and object file names
 should not be used as arguments.
Explanations about Options.-x:
Turn off any specification of a language, so that subsequent files are handled
 according to their file name suffixes (as they are if -x has not been used at all).

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

Explanations about Options.-sL:
Scan)
 The list scan is a degenerate form of host discovery that simply lists each host of
 the network(s) specified, without sending any packets to the target hosts. By default,
 Nmap still does reverse-DNS resolution on the hosts to learn their names. It is often
 surprising how much useful information simple hostnames give out. For example, fw.chi
 is the name of one company's Chicago firewall.
Explanations about Options.-R:
(DNS resolution for all targets)
 Tells Nmap to always do reverse DNS resolution on the target IP addresses. Normally
 reverse DNS is only performed against responsive (online) hosts.
Explanations about Options.-n: Tells Nmap to never do reverse DNS

echo.-n: do not output the trailing newline

xxd.mpsum: make a hexdump or do the reverse.
xxd.-i:
| -include
 Output in C include file style. A complete static array definition is written
 (named after the input file), unless xxd reads from stdin.
xxd.-p:
| -ps | -postscript | -plain
 Output in postscript continuous hexdump style. Also known as plain hexdump style.
xxd.-a:
| -autoskip
 Toggle autoskip: A single '*' replaces nul-lines. Default off.
xxd.-l:
len | -len len
 Stop after writing <len> octets.
